content.prompt: Chicken hatcheries employ workers to determine the sex of the baby chicks. The hatcheries claim that the workers are correct 95 percent of the time. An investigator believes the workersâ€™ success rate (workers are correct) is actually less than 95 percent of the time. The investigator selects a random sample of chicks and finds that the hatchery workers had a success rate of 0.936. The conditions for inference were checked and verified, and the p-value of the test was given as 0.0322. If the null hypothesis is true, which of the following statements is a correct interpretation of the p-value?

choices.label: Of all possible samples of the same size, 3.22% will result in a success rate of 93.6% or less.
Of all possible samples of the same size, 3.22% will result in a success rate of 93.6% or more.
Of all possible samples of the same size, 3.22% will result in a success rate of 95% or less.
Of all possible samples of the same size, 3.22% will result in a success rate of 95% or more.
Of all possible samples of the same size, 3.22% will result in a success rate of less than 93.6% or more than 96.4%.

skill.text: Skill 4.B: Interpret statistical calculations and findings to assign meaning or assess a claim.
